RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 18th September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded tentatively following the cautious gains on Wall St amid positioning heading into a flurry of central bank activity
  • NY Fed are to to conduct another USD 75bln overnight repo today between 1315-1330BST at a minimum bid rate of 2.10% (unchanged from Tuesday
  • Saudi Energy Minister Abdulaziz said oil supply is fully back online and that it will keep full oil supply to its customers this month
  • Saudi Arabia’s Defence Ministry will conduct a press conference today which will reportedly show evidence of Iranian involvement
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK & EZ CPI, US Building Permits, Housing Starts, Canadian CPI, New Zealand GDP, FOMC Rate Decision & Fed’s Powell’s Press Conference, BCB Rate Decision, ECB’s de Guindos and de Galhau, Riksbank’s Ingves

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded tentatively following the cautious gains on Wall St amid positioning heading into a flurry of central bank activity including the FOMC decision where the Fed are expected to deliver a consecutive 25bps cut. ASX 200 (-0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) were indecisive ahead of the looming risk events and with Australia subdued by losses in the energy sector after an aggressive pullback in oil prices due to reports Saudi oil output will return to normal levels quicker than initially anticipated, while the Japanese benchmark remained at the whim of a choppy currency amid somewhat inconclusive data which showed Exports contracted for a 9th consecutive month albeit at a narrower than expected decline. Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) conformed to the holding pattern seen across regional and global counterparts after the PBoC opted for a net neutral position in its liquidity operations and after President Trump reverted back to a blasé approach on US-China trade in which he suggested a deal could come soon, possibly before the 2020 election or after. Finally, 10yr JGBs initially continued to oscillate around the 154.00 level as the BoJ kick-started its 2-day policy meeting, although prices eventually gained traction after tripping stops through this week’s resistance levels and largely ignored the mostly weaker 20yr JGB auction results.

 

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0728 vs. Exp. 7.0646 (Prev. 7.0730)

 

US President Trump said a US-China trade deal could come soon possibly before the 2020 election or after, while he suggested that China believes he is going to win the election but wants someone else to. (Newswires)

 

Japanese Trade Balance Total Yen (Aug) -136.3B vs. Exp. -355.9B (Prev. -249.6B, Rev. -250.7B). (Newswires) Japanese Exports YY (Aug) -8.2% vs. Exp. -10.9% (Prev. -1.6%, Rev. -1.5%); 9th consecutive contraction.

Japanese Imports YY (Aug) -12.0% vs. Exp. -11.2% (Prev. -1.2%)

 

UK/EU

UK opposition Labour Party Leader Corbyn said he would remain neutral and let the people decide on Brexit in a 2nd referendum if he were to be PM. (Guardian)

 

In response to EU comments that no alternative ‘concrete’ proposals to the backstop have been submitted by the UK, sources state that the UK are showing papers outlining PM Johnson’s position to the EU, but are not leaving the documents with them; over concerns of potential leaks. (Sky)

 

UK PM Johnson’s treatment at the hands of Luxembourg PM Bettel acts as a reminder as to why the UK wants to leave the EU, according to US ambassador Woody Johnson. (Telegraph)

 

The Bank of England should hold interest rates at 0.75% this week but signal that borrowing costs may need to rise if PM Johnson secures a Brexit deal by October 31, according to the Times’ shadow MPC. (Times)

 

The appointment of the next BoE Governor is due to be delayed until after the potentially forthcoming election with Governor Carney set to be asked to extend his term in the event of another Brexit delay, according to sources. (FT)

 

ECB's Villeroy said that Euro Area governments such as Germany and Netherlands should exploit fiscal leeway to support growth, while he warned that currency devaluations create risk of a trade war and can also exert inflationary pressures. (Newswires)

 

Spain is reportedly heading to snap elections after the King stated there was no candidate for parliament investiture vote. (El Pais)

 

GLOBAL

World Bank President Malpass said 2019 nominal world GDP growth is set to decelerate to less than 3% which is ‘a big let down’ from the nominal growth of about 6% in 2017 and 2018. (Newswires)

Exit polls suggested the Israeli election is too close to call as Channel 12 exit poll sees 57 seats for Netanyahu bloc, 55 for centre-left and 8 for outsider Lieberman, while Reshet TV exit poll sees 54 seats for Netanyahu right wing bloc, 58 for centre-left and 8 for outsider Liberman. (Newswires)

 

FX

 

DXY was flat near the prior day’s lows after the Fed’s unscheduled and first repo operation in a decade as it sought to soothe fears of a liquidity squeeze in the repo market rate in which its actions resulted to about a USD 53.2bln injection into the banking system, while it also announced to conduct another USD 75bln overnight repo later. Nonetheless, focus remained firmly on the upcoming FOMC announcement in which rates are widely expected to be cut again and where participants will also get to mull over the latest dot plot projections, although there has been turbulence in Fed Fund Futures overnight which briefly priced in just a 51% probability for a cut today from a 92% chance a week ago, before rising back to around 62%. EUR/USD traded uneventfully as it held on to the recent gains against the greenback and GBP/USD also consolidated after failing to hold above 1.2500. USD/JPY largely reflected the cautiousness in the region, while antipodeans were the laggards following a weaker than expected PBoC reference rate setting, as well as lacklustre Australian Westpac Consumer Sentiment and mixed New Zealand Current Account data.

Australian Westpac Leading Index (Aug) M/M -0.3% (Prev. 0.1%, Rev. 0.2%). (Newswires) New Zealand Current Account (Q2) Q/Q -1.1B vs. Exp. -1.1B (Prev. 0.7B). (Newswires) New Zealand Current Account- Annual (Q2) -10.2B vs. Exp. -10.1B (Prev. -10.6B) New Zealand Current Account/GDP (Q2) -3.4% vs. Exp. -3.4% (Prev. -3.6%)

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were lacklustre in which WTI languished around the USD 59.00/bbl level after prices dropped around 6% after reports that Saudi oil output will return to normal levels quicker than initially anticipated, while a surprise build in headline API crude stockpiles added to the aggressive pullback for oil. Gold traded sideways overnight and just about held on to the USD 1500/oz whilst copper prices were also flat in reflection of the non-committal tone across asset classes.

 

API Crude Inventories +0.592mln vs. Exp. -2.5mln (Prev. -7.2mln). (Newswires)

 

Saudi Energy Minister Abdulaziz said oil supply is fully back online and resumed as before after more than half the oil output was resumed in the past few days and that it will keep full oil supply to its customers this month. Furthermore, he added that Saudi markets will be fully back online by the end of September with production to reach 11mln BPD by September 30th and that they will continue to withdraw stocks for its exports, while production will be at 9.89mln BPD in October and reach 12mln BPD by the end of November. (Newswires)

 

Saudi Aramco CEO confirmed Abqaiq is producing 2mln BPD currently and reiterated that all needed facilities to restore production will be completed by the end of the month. Saudi Aramco CEO they are still in the process of estimating the repair work but considered their size it is not that significant, while he also stated that the IPO should be ready within a year but dependent on market conditions. (Newswires)

 

US President Trump said he does not believe the release of the US SPR is necessary as oil prices have not gone up very much. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump administration is reportedly considering a range of options to retaliate against Iran including cyberattack or physical strike on Iran's oil facilities or Revolutionary Guards assets. (NBC)

 

Saudi Arabia Defence Ministry will conduct a press conference today which will show evidence of Iran involvement and that Iranian weapons were used in Aramco attacks, according to state TV. In other news, Saudi Arabia has decided to join the international alliance for safety and protection of maritime navigation. (Newswires)

 

French President Macron spoke to Saudi Crown Prince MBS through telephone in which Macron stated the world should show no weakness against Aramco attacks. (Newswires)

 

US

Markets are waiting for the Fed. Yields were lower across the curve by between 2-4bps at settlement, and the shape of the curve had bull-flattened again, with major curve spreads narrowing by around 1bps, or so. The FOMC is expected to deliver a 25bps rate cut at Wednesday's meeting, but the pricing has today become more balanced, at around 50/50 (compared to 70/30 on Monday, weighted towards a 25bps cut; there is no pricing for a 50bps cut in September). US T-note futures (Z9) settled 7 ticks higher at 129-09.

NY Fed announced to conduct another USD 75bln overnight repo on Wednesday between 08:15 to 08:30 ET at a minimum bid rate of 2.10% (unchanged from Tuesday). (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia traded cautious amid pre-FOMC positioning
content: Asia equity markets traded tentative following the cautious gains on Wall St amid positioning heading into a flurry of central bank activity including the FOMC decision where the Fed are expected to deliver a consecutive 25bps cut. ASX 200 (-0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) were indecisive ahead of the looming risk events and with Australia subdued by losses in the energy sector after an aggressive pullback in oil prices due to reports Saudi oil output will return to normal levels quicker than initially anticipated, while the Japanese benchmark remained at the whim of a choppy currency amid somewhat inconclusive data which showed Exports contracted for a 9th consecutive month albeit at a narrower than expected decline. Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) conformed to the holding pattern seen across regional and global counterparts after the PBoC opted for a net neutral position in its liquidity operations and after President Trump reverted back to a blasé approach on US-China trade in which he suggested a deal could come soon, possibly before the 2020 election or after. Finally, 10yr JGBs initially continued to oscillate around the 154.00 level as the BoJ kick-started its 2-day policy meeting, although prices eventually gained traction after tripping stops through this week’s resistance levels and largely ignored the mostly weaker 20yr JGB auction results.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades with cautious gains amid pre-FOMC positioning
content:
Asia equity markets trade tentative following the cautious gains on Wall St amid positioning heading into a flurry of central bank activity including the FOMC decision where the Fed are expected to deliver a consecutive 25bps cut. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) are mixed ahead of the looming risk events and with Australia subdued by losses in the energy sector after an aggressive pullback in oil prices due to reports Saudi oil output will return to normal levels quicker than initially anticipated, while the Japanese benchmark remains afloat on recent JPY weakness but with gains restricted amid inconclusive data which showed Exports contracted for a 9th consecutive month albeit at a narrower than expected decline. Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) conform to the holding pattern seen across regional and global counterparts after the PBoC opted for a net neutral position in its liquidity efforts and with President Trump reverting back to a blasé approach on US-China trade in which he suggested a deal could come soon, possibly before the 2020 election or after.

In FX markets, the DXY is flat but remains near the prior day’s lows after the Fed’s unscheduled and first repo operation in a decade as it sought to soothe fears of a liquidity squeeze in the repo market rate in which its actions resulted to about a USD 53.2bln injection into the banking system, while it also announced to conduct another USD 75bln overnight repo later. Nonetheless, focus remains firmly on the upcoming FOMC announcement in which rates are widely expected to be cut again and where participants will also get to mull over the latest dot plot projections, although there has been turbulence in Fed Fund Futures overnight which briefly priced in just a 51% probability for a cut today from a 92% chance a week ago, before rising back to around 62%. EUR/USD trades uneventful as it holds on to the recent gains against the greenback and GBP/USD also consolidates after failing to hold above 1.2500. Elsewhere, USD/JPY has largely reflected the cautious gains in the region, while antipodeans are the regional laggards following a weaker than expected PBoC reference rate setting, as well as lacklustre Australian Westpac Consumer Sentiment and mixed New Zealand Current Account data.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher but with gains only modest as prices continue to oscillate around the 154.00 level ahead of a 20yr JGB auction later and with BoJ kick-starting its 2-day policy meeting.
